_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Ice Cream and Frozen Dessert Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.    Mia Products accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and emergency management practices.  All applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protective Agency (EPA) prevention program are adhered to.  Mia Products emergency response policy involves the preparation of an emergency response plan and the emergency response services in the community. Mia Products is in compliance with all OSHA and EPA Emergency Response Program requirements.

B.    Mia Product is a producer of novelty ice products.  On site we have 22,000 lbs. Anhydrous Ammonia.  Mia Products uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigeration to cool products and chill liquids.  The plant is normally manned around the clock, the only exception would be holidays.  On holidays the plant is monitored by an in-house alarm system that is monitored by EST security.

C.    The offsite consequence analysis includes consideration of two anhydrous ammonia release scenarios, identified as ?worst case release? and ?alternative scenario?.  First scenario is defined by EPA, which states that the owner or operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes, due to an unspecific failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as ?more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario?.  

The worst-case release scenario at Mia Products involves a failure of the receiver, which is connected, to the 22,000 lb system.  The offsite consequence analysis for the scenario was performed for the two sets of conditions.  The first set followed conditions pre-defined by the EPA, namely release of the entire amount as a gas in 10 minutes, using of the one hour average ERPG-3 as the toxic endpoint, and consideration of the population residing within the full circle with radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distant.  EPA set these conditions to facility the performance of the offsite consequence analysi

s.

EPA mandated metrological conditions, namely Stability F, wind speed of 1.5m/sec., highest daily maximum temperature (116 degrees F.) and average humidity (65%0 were used for both sets.

When atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst-case scenario was performed the EPA assumptions, a distance to toxic endpoint of 1.8 miles and an estimated residence population potential affected 2750.

The alternate release scenario involves the rupture of a pipe.  The amount of release anhydrous ammonia released is 24 lbs./min. at the average rate over one hour (the duration of the release) of 44lbs./min.  Toxic endpoint distance to ERPG-2 and ?3 levels were obtained.  The latter is defined as IDLH as ?the maximum airborne concentration below which that individuals could be exposed for up to without experience or developing life threat ting health effects?.  The typical meteorological conditions used were Stability E, Wind Speed 3m/sec, Average Temperature 62 degrees F., and 63% average humidity.  The estimated distance traveled to the toxic endpoint is .43 miles.  The estimated of residence population affected is 1520.

D.    Mia Products accident release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
a.    High level of training of the operators and maintenance personnel.
b.    Preventive maintenance program.
c.    Use of state-of-art- process and safety equipment.
d.    Use of accurate and effective operating procedures written with the participation of the operators.
e.    Performance of a hazard analysis of equipment and procedures.
f.    Implementation of an audit and inspection program.

Preventive steps include availability of Full Face Mask both Canister and Cartridges, self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), Class A Suits, Class B Suits, MSA DragonFly alarms, Motorola communication devices (two way earpieces), hand held ammonia detectors, fixed ammonia detectors, and training (Technician Level).  The maintenance mechanic?s uses equipment during offensive and defensive p

rocedures for the anhydrous ammonia system, along with training exercises in preparation for an emergency response.  All plant personnel are made aware of the hazardous and toxic properties of anhydrous ammonia during orientation training.  

E.    No accidental release of anhydrous ammonia at levels of or exceeding limit threshold (100lbs) has occurred at this facility in the past five years.

F. Mia Products has an emergency response program, which has been coordinated with Moosic Police Department, DATOM (County Haz. Mat Team), Greenwood and Moosic Fire Department, which are all members of the Lackawanna County Emergency Planning Committee (LCEPC).  This program includes an emergency response decision tree and a notification plan.  All parties involved in the emergency response program review emergency procedures annually.
